children.text: Former President Donald Trump said today that he‚Äôll ensure cryptocurrency can be used for his campaign donations.
The former president and leading Republican candidate for next year‚Äôs election held $2.8 million in a cryptocurrency wallet as of early August, according to¬†
official
documents

¬†governmental ethics watchdog Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington received Monday. He also earned $4.87 million in licensing fees from his non-fungible token collection, per the filing. Trump, despite being a¬†
crypto skeptic when he was president
, last year debuted a non-fungible token (
NFT
) project called¬†
Trump Digital Collectible Cards
¬†sporting images of himself. He released a second series of collectibles this April. Both collections¬†

children.text: Former President Donald Trump has recently showcased a notable shift in his stance toward Bitcoin, diverging from his historically critical view of cryptocurrencies.

‚ÄúFrankly, it‚Äôs taken a life of its own, you probably have to do some regulation, as you know,‚Äù Trump suggested, acknowledging the currency‚Äôs burgeoning momentum and its increasing incorporation into payment systems.
‚ÄúMany people are embracing it. And more and more, I‚Äôm seeing people wanting to pay [with] Bitcoin,‚Äù he added, highlighting the digital currency‚Äôs growing acceptance.

children.text: Although Trump said he was¬†
"not a fan" of cryptocurrency in July 2019

, he appeared enthusiastic to promote his new collection. "GET YOUR CARDS NOW! Only $99 each! Would make a great Christmas gift. Don‚Äôt Wait. They will be gone, I believe, very quickly!" he wrote in a post on his platform.

‚ÄúInstead of attacking industries of the future, we will embrace them, including making America the world capital for crypto and Bitcoin,‚Äù Trump told the audience at an Economic Club of New York gathering.

urls.description: The likely GOP flag bearer in the upcoming U.S. presidential election signaled his friendliness to crypto at a Mar-a-Lago event earlier this month.
urls.title: Trump Becomes First Major Party Candidate to Accept Crypto Donations

children.text: Vice President Harris said she would ‚Äúencourage innovative technologies like AI and digital assets while protecting our consumers and investors‚Äù as President during comments made at a Wall Street fundraiser, according to a Bloomberg reporter present.¬†
Vance has disclosed Bitcoin¬†¬†holdings valued at up to $250,000, which at the time of writing is around 6.5 BTC,¬†
according
¬†to CoinGecko. He was also backed by Bitcoin proponent and billionaire investor Peter Thiel through a Super PAC. Bloomberg¬†
reported
¬†on April 20 that Thiel donated $3.5 million to the Protect Ohio Values Super PAC.
Several Republican senators slammed the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) on Wednesday over its ‚Äúdeeply troubling‚Äù conduct in a recent case against the cryptocurrency company DEBT Box.
In a letter to SEC Chair¬†
Gary Gensler¬†
on Wednesday, Sens. JD Vance (R-Ohio),¬†
Thom Tillis¬†
Bill Hagerty¬†
(R-Tenn.),¬†
Cynthia Lummis¬†
(R-Wyo.) and¬†
Katie Britt¬†
(R-Ala.) expressed concerns about the agency‚Äôs conduct.

‚ÄúIt is unconscionable that any federal agency‚Äîespecially one regularly involved in highly consequential legal procedures and one that, under your leadership, has often pursued its regulatory mission through enforcement actions rather than rulemakings‚Äîcould operate in such an unethical and unprofessional manner,‚Äù the senators wrote.

children.text: Sen.¬†
J.D. Vance
¬†on Thursday plans to introduce a bill that would shield banks from regulatory pressure to cut off customers like crypto firms, gun manufacturers and oil and gas companies.
The Ohio Republican,¬†
in his latest attempt to put his stamp on banking policy
, told POLITICO in a statement that the legislation aims to ensure the banking system is governed by "apolitical oversight." Republican Sens.¬†
Cynthia Lummis
¬†of Wyoming and¬†
Roger Marshall
¬†of Kansas are co-sponsors.
‚ÄúFor far too long, federal regulators have focused on advancing the agenda of the far left at the expense of their core mission,‚Äù Vance said.

bill.summary:
For congressional disapproval under chapter 8 of title 5, United States Code, of the rule submitted by the Securities and Exchange Commission relating to "Staff Accounting Bulletin No. 121".

This staff accounting bulletin expresses the views of the staff regarding the accounting for obligations to safeguard crypto-assets an entity holds for platform users.
bill.title: Staff Accounting Bulletin No. 121
